name: Overview
data:
[{"id":"21c8f8b9-150d-4174-817b-a4357636c60a","type":"heading","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left","level":3,"isToggleable":false},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Class Documentation: ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"Pointer","styles":{"code":true}}],"children":[]},{"id":"32649854-e5b5-4aab-9148-48bc5a6f899a","type":"paragraph","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"The ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"Pointer","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" class is the foundational building block for value tracking in the Jarvis analysis engine. It represents a variable or expression as a "points-to" set. In static analysis, because a variable might hold different values depending on the execution path (such as inside an ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"if-else","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" block), a ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"Pointer","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" stores all possible items in a unique set rather than tracking just one.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"e5c1052d-da42-4d37-ae96-8d0ab2e289ef","type":"divider","props":{},"children":[]},{"id":"97e6db52-f808-4060-a323-7983aa5eaf87","type":"heading","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left","level":4,"isToggleable":false},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Attributes","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"c0d0036e-497b-4158-ae89-12960aafd91d","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"values","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"set","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"): The internal collection of tracked items. Using a set ensures that the pointer only stores unique definitions or values, avoiding redundancy during analysis.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"46dfb25d-db4a-42a8-9298-d65523b26eea","type":"divider","props":{},"children":[]},{"id":"4cb110c3-164a-42a1-ba7d-85edfc7d83a0","type":"heading","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left","level":4,"isToggleable":false},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Methods","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"d3420533-9626-4b35-97f4-f5bf6dd3cafb","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"__init__()
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"Initializes a new Pointer instance with an empty set of values.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"b4467ddc-3c2f-476c-986a-1c38a9e92a4b","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"add(item)
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"Adds a single item to the pointer's set of possible values.","styles":{}}],"children":[{"id":"5aa1c52f-7a35-4c6e-ac7d-7f983b1c33a8","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"item","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":": The value or definition identifier to track.","styles":{}}],"children":[]}]},{"id":"c9c38238-a382-4b9f-91d2-62a6305bec04","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"add_set(s)
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"Performs a union operation between the current values and an external set. This is used to add multiple values at once.","styles":{}}],"children":[{"id":"58cd898b-d959-4f84-8c69-19f325d97c50","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"s","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":": A set of items to be integrated.","styles":{}}],"children":[]}]},{"id":"828ae3a2-8f89-4589-a78f-a8d098ce1356","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"get()
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"Retrieves the current set of values being tracked by the pointer.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"8382900c-dfd0-4543-b759-76cec10ae072","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"merge(pointer)
","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":"Merges another ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"Pointer","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" object into the current one. This is a critical operation for control-flow analysis (e.g., merging the results of two different branches).","styles":{}}],"children":[{"id":"7cca9e4f-f75d-4856-8888-1c6671bdc267","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"pointer","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":": Another ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"Pointer","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" instance whose values should be combined with this one.","styles":{}}],"children":[]}]},{"id":"90035cc9-5976-462e-b1f0-1fb21b87b201","type":"divider","props":{},"children":[]},{"id":"cce85b88-9d90-44e6-8d2c-4edef9555898","type":"heading","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left","level":3,"isToggleable":false},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Usage Example","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"69b8d812-9b6b-4853-9255-bc684717fcb9","type":"paragraph","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"The ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"Pointer","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" class is used whenever the analyzer needs to represent what a variable might "point to."","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"b839a49b-5827-402a-8b76-6b775a1cc9ef","type":"codeBlock","props":{"language":"python"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"from pointers import Pointer

# 1. Initialize pointers for two different code branches
branch_a = Pointer()
branch_b = Pointer()

# 2. Simulate assignments in different branches
# branch_a: x = "user_service"
# branch_b: x = "admin_service"
branch_a.add("user_service")
branch_b.add("admin_service")

# 3. Create a master pointer for the variable after the branches meet
variable_x = Pointer()
variable_x.merge(branch_a)
variable_x.merge(branch_b)

# 4. Check the possible values for 'x'
print(f"Variable x could point to: {variable_x.get()}")
# Output: Variable x could point to: {'user_service', 'admin_service'}

# 5. Add a set of additional possibilities
additional_paths = {"guest_service", "system_service"}
variable_x.add_set(additional_paths)","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"fa5e1275-9e29-49e5-a878-790397174cf4","type":"heading","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left","level":3,"isToggleable":false},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Insights","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"c2ab08fa-dee2-4711-9611-6c3362108eaa","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Path Sensitivity","styles":{"bold":true}},{"type":"text","text":": By using sets and the ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"merge","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" method, ","styles":{}},{"type":"text","text":"Pointer","styles":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" allows the system to remain "path-sensitive," meaning it remembers all possible origins of a variable's data.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"226341fd-403f-405c-9a50-280c1db02190","type":"bulletListItem","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Identity Tracking","styles":{"bold":true}},{"type":"text","text":": In most Jarvis implementations, the "items" added to the pointer are not the actual data values, but identifiers or keys pointing to definitions in the Global Symbol Table.","styles":{}}],"children":[]},{"id":"967dfc33-392b-4634-8b88-aa3104e55363","type":"paragraph","props":{"backgroundColor":"default","textColor":"default","textAlignment":"left"},"content":[],"children":[]}]
